newsitem.title: TURKEY: Cyprus missiles unlikely to be deployed - US envoy.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus missiles unlikely to be deployed - US envoy.

text.p: U.S. envoy Carey Cavanaugh said on Wednesday he believed the Cyprus government would abandon a plan to buy Russian-made missiles that has angered Turkey.
"It is my personal expectation those missiles will never come to the island," Cavanaugh told reporters on arrival at Ankara airport from Athens.
Cavanaugh repeated U.S. objections to the planned Greek Cypriot purchase of S-300 anti-aircraft missiles, due on the island in 16 months.
"This is not something we support. This is not something we favour and this is not something we will favour in 16 months. The solution has to be found," he said.
He said Washington also opposed Turkish threats to halt the deployment by force. "No aggressive response can be justified or accepted."
Both sides on Cyprus have denied the missile crisis is over, despite Cavanaugh's comments that the row has been defused.
